item.title: JAGS tutorial with replication of Joseph, et al
item.description: Objective and Motivation My goal for this document is to teach the basic principles of conducting a Bayesian analysis of diagnostic data in JAGS (“Just Another Gibbs Sampler”). I am assuming a basic knowledge of Bayesian ideas, such as the definition of a prior, posterior, and likelihood. I will also not be explaining the concept of a Gibbs sampler (for that I recommend John Kruschke’s islands example). Rather, I’ll focus on creating a user-friendly document showing how to implement these ideas.

item.title: Nathaniel Hendrix.
item.description: I’m a PhD candidate at the University of Washington’s Comparative Health Outcomes, Policy, and Economics (CHOICE) Institute. I previously earned my PharmD in 2015, also from the University of Washington. My research interests are in health economics, pharmacoepidemiology, and the application of artificial intelligence to healthcare.
